item.description: <div><img src="http://www.itnonline.com/sites/default/files/AI%20GettyImages-2155008807.jpg" style="width: 100%;" /><div>Dec. 1, 2025 — Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley and University of California, San Francisco have released Pillar (Pillar-0), an open-source AI model that analyzes medical images and recognizes conditions with an unprecedented degree of diagnostic accuracy. Unlike existing tools that are limited to a handful of conditions or models primarily designed for 2D images, Pillar-0 interprets 3D volumes directly and can recognize hundreds of conditions from a single CT or MRI exam.</div></div>
item.dc:creator: Imaging Technology News

item.description: <div><img src="https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/4187653/15566025/ultramansk_AdobeStock_1672779636_RV.jpg" style="width: 100%;" /><div>In 2025, 20.0% of EU enterprises with 10 or more employees used artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to conduct their business, showing a solid growth of 6.5 percentage points (pp) from 13.5% in 2024. Compared with 2021 (7.7%) and 2023 (8.1%), the use of AI technologies is becoming more popular among EU businesses. The highest shares of these enterprises in 2025 were in Denmark (42.0%), Finland (37.8%) and Sweden (35.0%). At the other end were Romania (5.2%), Poland (8.4%) and Bulgaria (8.5%). Almost all EU countries recorded increases in the share of enterprises using AI technologies compared with the previous year. Denmark registered the highest increase (+14.5 pp), followed by Finland (+13.5 pp) and Lithuania (+12.5 pp). Source dataset: isoc_eb_ai The most common use of AI technology by EU enterprises was to analyse written language (11.8%). This was followed by AI use to generate pictures, videos, sound/audio (9.5%), written or spoken language (8.8%) and to convert spoken language into machine-readable format (7.2%). Compared with 2024, the use of AI technology that grew the most in 2025 was analysing written language (+4.9 pp), followed by the generation of written or spoken language (+3.4%). Source dataset: isoc_eb_ai</div></div>
item.dc:creator: Eurostat

item.description: <div><img src="https://restauranttechnologynews.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/daves-hot-chicken-sligo-drive-madison-wi-building-full-view.webp" style="width: 100%;" /><div>Dave’s Hot Chicken has been one of the breakout restaurant stories of the past decade, growing from a $900 parking lot pop-up in East Hollywood to a fast-casual chain with more than 300 locations, systemwide [...]</div></div>
item.dc:creator: RTN Editors

item.description: <div><img src="https://images.sidearmdev.com/fit?url=https://dxbhsrqyrr690.cloudfront.net/sidearm.nextgen.sites/stevens.sidearmsports.com/images/2025/12/10/12-10-25_MBB_Teaser.jpg&height=450&width=800&type=jpeg" style="width: 100%;" /><div>Schenectady, N.Y. – The Stevens Institute of Technology men's basketball team shot 43 percent from three-point territory, but dropped a 79-66 non-conference contest to the Union Garnet Chargers on Wednesday night.</div></div>
item.dc:creator: Stevens Institute of Technology Athletics
Lillian Baldi

item.description: <div><img src="https://cdn.mediaplaynews.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/hdr10advancedlogo.jpg" style="width: 100%;" /><div>HDR10+ Technologies — a multi-industry association that encompasses more than 170 adopters and nearly 20,000 certified devices — announced that it will soon commence the licensing and certification of devices, content, and services that support HDR10+ Advanced dynamic metadata technology, the latest in a series of enhancements to the HDR10+ ecosystem. HDR10+ dynamic metadata offers … Continue reading "HDR10+ Technologies Launching HDR10+ Advanced"</div></div>
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Prange
